notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Einstein 1 Sales, and Developer editions
notes.breaking_changes: Prebuilt ECI measures are not available for new setups in Spring '26.

notes.feature_name: Sales Performance Management
notes.description: Refine territory design in complex markets by assigning shared boundaries to multiple sales areas. Distribute financial targets directly to accounts while accounting for existing bottom-up goals. Plus, streamline the sales planning process by generating quota plans based on territory alignments to keep data synchronized.

notes.feature_name: Salesforce Maps and Salesforce Maps Advanced
notes.description: Map crucial proprietary and third-party data when you integrate it with your Salesforce data. Reveal sales opportunities on partner sites. And visualize planned field visits compared with past visit metrics.

notes.feature_name: Create quota plans from territory hierarchy
notes.description: Create quota plans from territory hierarchy, owner, and attribute data within sales plan segments. Design territories with current Salesforce data. And distribute work fairly among sales teams that don't rely on geographic boundaries.

notes.feature_name: Design Territories with Shared Boundaries
notes.description: Refine your territory design in densely populated areas by allowing a single boundary, such as a postal code, to be assigned to multiple sales areas. This new capability is supported only for live data alignments and gives you more customization when modeling complex geographic territories like New York City or London. Units, however, can still only be assigned to a single area. Utilize area-level assignment rules to ensure units are correctly mapped when areas overlap.

notes.feature_name: Allocate Financial Targets to Accounts in Territory Planning
notes.description: Distribute top-down financial targets directly to accounts within Territory Planning. You can split targets evenly, weight them based on criteria like annual revenue, or distribute by defined segments. To ensure realistic planning, the allocation logic respects existing bottom-up targets set by the field. This alignment simplifies the transition from territory design to quota planning.

notes.feature_name: Enjoy Improved Performance in Territory Planning
notes.description: Create territories for your sales teams with confidence, efficiency, and trust. Territory Planning provides enhanced security, reliable scalability, and better performance for some resource-intensive functionality.

notes.feature_name: Create Alignment-Based Quota Plans
notes.description: Streamline the planning process by creating quota plans directly from existing territory alignments. Planners can now view account-level details and metadata within the quota planning interface to inform target setting. Because the plans share data, updates to territory models flow into the quota plan, ensuring assignments and targets remain synchronized.

notes.feature_name: Sales Planning Version 1 is Scheduled for Retirement
notes.description: Sales Planning version 1 is scheduled for retirement in Summer ’26.

notes.feature_name: Design Territories with Shared Boundaries
notes.description: Refine your territory design in densely populated areas by allowing a single boundary, such as a postal code, to be assigned to multiple sales areas. This new capability is supported only for live data alignments and gives you more customization when modeling complex geographic territories like New York City or London. Units, however, can still only be assigned to a single area. Utilize area-level assignment rules to ensure units are correctly mapped when areas overlap.
notes.edition: Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions with Web Services API enabled

notes.feature_name: Allocate Financial Targets to Accounts in Territory Planning
notes.description: Distribute top-down financial targets directly to accounts within Territory Planning. You can split targets evenly, weight them based on criteria like annual revenue, or distribute by defined segments. To ensure realistic planning, the allocation logic respects existing bottom-up targets set by the field. This alignment

notes.feature_name: Quota Planning Integration
notes.description: Simplifies the transition from territory design to quota planning. Configure a goal within an alignment connected to a segment data source to enable allocation options. Use an allocation formula to distribute targets using even, weighted, or bucketed methods, while automatically subtracting any existing bottom-up targets from the total. You can also import overrides or publish targets to use them in downstream quota planning.

notes.feature_name: Improved Performance in Territory Planning
notes.description: Territory Planning provides enhanced security, reliable scalability, and better performance for some resource-intensive functionality. When you optimize a territory plan, the job now runs on Hyperforce, the Salesforce public cloud infrastructure with integrated standards for compliance, security, agility, and scalability. When you publish territories to Salesforce Field Service, the job that generates KML files runs more efficiently. However, in some limited geographies, viewing these published territories in Field Service can cause a slight degradation of shapes.

notes.feature_name: Alignment-Based Quota Plans
notes.description: Streamline the planning process by creating quota plans directly from existing territory alignments. Planners can now view account-level details and metadata within the quota planning interface to inform target setting. Because the plans share data, updates to territory models flow into the quota plan, ensuring assignments and targets remain synchronized. This integration provides visibility into account-specific metadata, such as historical revenue, helping to balance quotas fairly even when territory structures are complex or shifting.

notes.feature_name: Territory Alignment for Quota Plans
notes.description: Select a territory alignment when creating a new quota plan to import the area hierarchy and account data. The hierarchy remains read-only within the quota plan to preserve the territory structure, but you can view account details and allocate targets based on the imported areas. If the source territory changes, such as a deleted area, the system flags the mismatch and prompts you to accept changes to keep the plans aligned.

notes.feature_name: Sales Planning Version 1 Retirement
notes.description: Sales Planning version 1 is scheduled for retirement in Summer ’26.

notes.feature_name: Retirement of Exchange Web Services
notes.description: Microsoft announced the retirement of Exchange Web Services (EWS) starting October 1, 2026. Lightning Sync configurations that use EWS won’t capture or sync data from Microsoft after EWS is retired.

notes.feature_name: Retirement of Salesforce for Outlook
notes.description: Full product retirement for Salesforce for Outlook is scheduled for December 2027.

notes.feature_name: Adopt Authorized Email Domains (Release Update)
notes.description: Salesforce is retiring the existing exemption process for disabling email change verifications, and authorized email domains provide the same benefit. This update is available starting in Spring ’26. The process to disable email change verification relied on a manual change by Salesforce Customer Support, which created operational inefficiencies and potential risks. With authorized email domains, you simplify the onboarding process for new users by using domain-level email verification. Email verification is bypassed for users with email addresses on a domain that you trust.
notes.timeline: Salesforce enforces this update in Winter ’27.
notes.breaking_changes: Retirement of the existing exemption process for disabling email change verifications.
notes.security_notes: These changes relate to the verification of email addresses stored in Salesforce and the ability to send email from Salesforce. There’s no change to the requirements for account verification for access to Salesforce.

notes.feature_name: Accurate Event and Email Sync Monitoring
notes.description: Accurately monitor event and email syncing with detailed insights and reports on failure. Extend the scope of your Account, Contact, Opportunity, and Lead reports by integrating detailed email insights in your reports.

notes.feature_name: Migrate Microsoft 365 Authentication to Microsoft Graph
notes.description: Transition your Einstein Activity Capture’s Microsoft 365 authentication from Exchange Web Services (EWS) to Microsoft Graph, which is more modern, secure, and scalable. Microsoft is retiring EWS in October 2026, so switch to Microsoft Graph to avoid service disruption. Proactive notifications and a single-click tool make the migration process smooth.

notes.feature_name: Include Email Insights in Custom Report Types
notes.description: Extend the scope of your Account, Contact, Opportunity, and Lead reports by integrating detailed email insights such as message type and content in your reports. Insights like these provide a more holistic view of your sales activities and help you stay on top of important customer communications.

notes.feature_name: Monitor Accurate Event and Email Sync with Detailed Metrics and Failure Reports
notes.description: Get clear insights into event and email sync status with accurate metrics. For example, identify and resolve setup issues more effectively and improve user trust with sync failure reports.

notes.feature_name: Make Captured Emails Available as Activity Data
notes.description: Use an option in Setup to update Einstein Activity Capture and migrate previously captured email to Salesforce activity data. With this update and migration, all new email data and previously captured email data are synced, stored, and available as activity data. This update and migration makes email data available to platform tools and operations. After you start the update and migration process, it runs and is completed automatically.

notes.feature_name: Retirement of Synced Calendar Overlay
notes.description: If Show Synced and Captured Events is turned on, Einstein Activity Capture users access a view-only copy of events from Microsoft or Google on their Calendar. Some customers mistook the view-only events as duplicate calendar entries, so we’re retiring this feature.

notes.feature_name: Prepare for Activity 360 Reporting, Activity Metrics, and Activities Analytics Dashboard Retirement
notes.description: Before these tools retire, we recommend turning on Sync Email as Salesforce Activity for Einstein Activity Capture and configuring reports to explore data captured from email.

notes.feature_name: Migration to Microsoft Graph for Einstein Activity Capture
notes.description: This migration is essential to align with Microsoft’s evolving security standards and to avoid potential disruptions as EWS reaches its end of life in October 2026. By transitioning to Microsoft Graph, Salesforce ensures that your organization remains compliant and competitive, with improved support for modern features and enhanced user-level authentication.
notes.edition: Starter, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, Einstein 1 Sales, Agentforce 1 Sales
notes.timeline: EWS end of life in October 2026

notes.feature_name: Include Email Insights in Custom Report Types
notes.description: Extend the scope of your Account, Contact, Opportunity, and Lead reports by integrating detailed email insights such as message type and content in your reports. Insights like these provide a more holistic view of your sales activities and help you stay on top of important customer communications.
notes.activation_required: Sync Email as Salesforce Activity must be enabled in Einstein Activity Capture
notes.edition: Starter, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, Einstein 1 Sales, Agentforce 1 Sales

notes.feature_name: Monitor Accurate Event and Email Sync with Detailed Metrics and Failure Reports
notes.description: Get clear insights into event and email sync status with accurate metrics. For example, identify and resolve setup issues more effectively and improve user trust with sync failure reports.
notes.edition: Starter, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, Einstein 1 Sales, Agentforce 1 Sales

notes.feature_name: Make Captured Emails Available as Activity Data by Updating Einstein Activity Capture
notes.description: Use an option in Setup to update Einstein Activity Capture and migrate previously captured email to Salesforce activity data. With this update and migration, all new email data and previously captured email data are synced, stored, and available as activity data. This update and migration makes email data available to platform tools and operations. After you start the update and migration process, it runs and is completed automatically.
notes.availability: Staggered release beginning late December 2025 in sandboxes and early 2026 in production.
notes.edition: Available in Lightning Experience in Starter, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, Einstein 1 Sales, and Agentforce 1 Sales editions. Also available with the Einstein for Sales, Sales Engagement, and Revenue Intelligence add-ons.
notes.timeline: Late December 2025 in sandboxes and early 2026 in production.
notes.security_notes: Offers more granular privacy and sharing settings for captured email data.

notes.feature_name: Synced Calendar Overlay Is Retiring
notes.description: If Show Synced and Captured Events is turned on, Einstein Activity Capture users access a view-only copy of events from Microsoft or Google on their Calendar. Some customers mistook the view-only events as duplicate calendar entries, so we’re retiring this feature.

notes.feature_name: Retirement of View-Only Calendar Overlay and Synced and Captured Events Setting
notes.description: The view-only calendar overlay and the Synced and Captured Events setting in Einstein Activity Capture is retiring. They’re no longer available unless previously turned on. If you turn it off, you can’t re-enable it.
notes.edition: Starter, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, Einstein 1 Sales, Agentforce 1 Sales

notes.feature_name: Retirement of Activity 360 Reporting, Activity Metrics, and Activities Analytics Dashboard
notes.description: Before these tools retire, we recommend turning on Sync Email as Salesforce Activity for Einstein Activity Capture and configuring reports to explore data captured from email. Starting in Summer ’25, Einstein Activity Capture can sync and store email data as Task and EmailMessage object records. With this new data structure you can explore and use email activity data with standard reports, SOQL, automation workflows, and APIs. Activity 360 Reporting, Activity Metrics, and Activities Analytics Dashboard aren’t available unless previously turned on. Additionally, data from these reporting tools that appears in other features, including Prospecting Center, Pipeline Inspection, and Einstein Conversation Insights, aren’t available unless previously configured.
notes.edition: Starter, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, Einstein 1 Sales, Agentforce 1 Sales
notes.breaking_changes: This change affects other features that use Einstein Activity Capture data, including Prospecting Center, Pipeline Inspection, and Einstein Conversation Insights.

notes.feature_name: Retirement of Unified Email and Related Components
notes.description: UnifiedEmail, UnifiedEmailParticipant, UnifiedMeeting, UnifiedMeetingParticipant, UnifiedTask, and UnifiedTaskParticipant will be retired.

notes.feature_name: Sync Email as Salesforce Activity
notes.description: To turn on Sync Email as Salesforce Activity, update Einstein Activity Capture and migrate previously captured email. Use the Update & Migrate option available in Setup. Sync Email as Salesforce Activity is enabled by default if you turned on Einstein Activity Capture in Summer ’25 or later.

notes.feature_name: Retirement of Exchange Web Services (EWS)
notes.description: Microsoft announced the retirement of Exchange Web Services (EWS) starting October 1, 2026. Lightning Sync configurations that use EWS won’t capture or sync data from Microsoft after EWS is retired. To prepare, review the Microsoft guidelines on migrating to Microsoft Graph, the recommended API for accessing Microsoft services. Or, plan to move from Lightning Sync to Einstein Activity Capture.
notes.edition: Available in Lightning Experience in Starter, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, and Einstein 1 Sales editions.

notes.feature_name: Salesforce for Outlook (Retiring)
notes.description: Full product retirement for Salesforce for Outlook is scheduled for December 2027. If you’re sticking with Salesforce for Outlook for now, you can access past release notes about the current version from the Trailblazer Community. For the latest integration with Microsoft Outlook, we recommend moving to our next-generation products, the Outlook integration and Einstein Activity Capture. These products replace Salesforce for Outlook features and give users new capabilities. We continue to introduce enhancements for these products every release.
notes.edition: Lightning Experience and Salesforce Classic in Contact Manager, Group, Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions
notes.breaking_changes: When Salesforce for Outlook is retired, it will no longer sync contacts, events, or tasks. Admins and users also lose access to Salesforce for Outlook features, such as the side panel.

notes.feature_name: Outlook Integration
notes.description: Outlook Integration replaces Salesforce for Outlook and gives users new capabilities, like the use of Agentforce for emails. Leverage the power of Agentforce directly from your Outlook integration to prepare for meetings, summarize records, and trigger custom actions.
notes.edition: Lightning Experience and Salesforce Classic in Essentials, Group

notes.feature_name: Agentforce Integration
notes.description: When Agentforce is enabled, it automatically appears in your Outlook integration. Click Agentforce to start using it.
notes.edition: Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions
notes.timeline: Available on a rolling basis starting December 2025

notes.feature_name: Gmail Integration
notes.description: Get immediate access to relevant CRM data alongside your email communication by accessing the Gmail integration directly within Sales Cloud Everywhere.

notes.feature_name: Access the Gmail Integration Directly in Sales Cloud Everywhere
notes.description: Get immediate access to relevant CRM data alongside your email communication by accessing the Gmail Integration directly within Sales Cloud Everywhere.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, and Developer editions
notes.timeline: Gmail Integration became available in Sales Cloud Everywhere in late June 2025.

notes.feature_name: Migrate Microsoft 365 Authentication in Inbox to Microsoft Graph
notes.description: Transition your Inbox’s Microsoft 365 authentication method from Exchange Web Services (EWS) to Microsoft Graph, which is more modern, secure, and scalable. Microsoft is retiring EWS in October 2026, so switch to Microsoft Graph to avoid service disruption.
notes.security_notes: This migration is essential to align with Microsoft’s evolving security standards.

notes.feature_name: Simplify Meeting Scheduling with a Redesigned Interface
notes.description: Give prospects a simpler and quicker way to schedule meetings with your sales team. When a user receives a scheduling link generated from Insert Availability in the Lightning Experience Email Composer, Gmail extension, or Outlook add-in, they’re taken to the new interface.

notes.feature_name: Transition to Microsoft Graph
notes.description: Salesforce is transitioning from EWS to Microsoft Graph to ensure organizations remain compliant and competitive, with improved support for modern features and enhanced user-level authentication.
notes.timeline: End of life for EWS in October 2026
notes.breaking_changes: Organizations must migrate to Microsoft Graph before EWS end of life.
notes.security_notes: Users are required to reconnect to their Microsoft 365 accounts to complete the connection transition.

notes.feature_name: Redesigned Meeting Scheduling Interface
notes.description: A new interface simplifies and speeds up the process for prospects to schedule meetings with the sales team. When users receive a scheduling link generated from Insert Availability in the Lightning Experience Email Composer, Gmail extension, or Outlook add-in, they are directed to the new interface.
notes.timeline: This change became available in December 2025.

notes.feature_name: Salesforce to Salesforce Is Being Retired
notes.description: Salesforce to Salesforce is being retired in Spring ’27. Salesforce has more powerful and integrated solutions that align with modern business needs. To prevent disruption when Salesforce ends support for the Salesforce to Salesforce product, make sure that you migrate your integrations to one of these recommended solutions: Partner Cloud, Data Cloud One, MuleSoft Anypoint, or MuleSoft for Flow.

notes.feature_name: New Sales Dialer Licenses Are No Longer Available
notes.description: New Sales Dialer licenses aren’t available for customers to purchase. We are planning to retire features and functionality for the product in the future.

notes.feature_name: Include Records from any Account on Account Plan Objectives
notes.description: Support sales account plans across account hierarchies by associating records from different accounts to an Account Plan Objective. Previously, you were limited to associating records linked directly to the account plan's primary account. Now, to build more comprehensive account plans, search for and add relevant records from any account. We delivered this feature due to your idea on IdeaExchange.

notes.feature_name: Salesforce to Salesforce Retirement
notes.description: Salesforce to Salesforce is being retired in Spring ’27. Salesforce has more powerful and integrated solutions that align with modern business needs. To prevent disruption when Salesforce ends support for the Salesforce to Salesforce product, make sure that you migrate your integrations to one of these recommended solutions: Partner Cloud, Data Cloud One, MuleSoft Anypoint, or MuleSoft for Flow.
notes.edition: Contact Manager, Group, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer editions
notes.timeline: Spring ’26: You can no longer turn on Salesforce to Salesforce in an org. Summer ’26: Support for Salesforce to Salesforce is discontinued. Spring ’27: Salesforce to Salesforce is fully retired in all orgs and no longer functions.

notes.feature_name: New Sales Dialer Licenses Retirement
notes.description: New Sales Dialer licenses aren’t available for customers to purchase. We are planning to retire features and functionality for the product in the future. To use telephony features directly in Salesforce, we recommend that you modernize your experience by moving to Service Cloud Voice.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited editions
notes.timeline: New licenses for Sales Dialer are no longer available.

notes.feature_name: Include Records from any Account on Account Plan Objectives
notes.description: Support sales account plans across account hierarchies by associating records from different accounts to an Account Plan Objective. Previously, you were limited to associating records linked directly to the account plan's primary account. Now, to build more comprehensive account plans, search for and add records from any account.

notes.feature_name: Enhanced Account Plan Objectives Calculation
notes.description: This feature enhances the calculation of account plan objectives to include relevant records from any account. This change was delivered due to user feedback on IdeaExchange.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Einstein 1 Sales Edition Editions

notes.feature_name: Improved Extensions in Salesforce CMS
notes.description: Previously known as Sidebar Extensions, Extensions in CMS have an improved development workflow. Users can build extensions to add productivity tools to their CMS content workflow, such as third-party generative AI tools or tone and grammar editors. Users can now choose which external content providers are available to their workspace and specify where to save files from these systems.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Control of Assets from External Content Providers
notes.description: Several new settings make it easier to manage external assets in an enhanced CMS workspace. Users can choose which providers are available to their workspace for greater administrative control and specify where to save the files. Previously, users could only save external assets directly in the workspace, but now they can choose their preferred folder.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Take Control of Assets from External Content Providers
notes.description: Several new settings make it easier to manage external assets in an enhanced CMS workspace. Choose which providers are available to your workspace for greater administrative control, and specify where to save the files. Previously, you could only save external assets directly in the workspace, but now you can choose your preferred folder.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions
notes.breaking_changes: If you previously installed external providers in Winter ’26, you must reselect the providers to make them accessible.

notes.feature_name: Flow Builder Enhancements
notes.description: Modify record-triggered and scheduled-triggered flows with Agentforce. Navigate through Flow Builder with collapsible paths and new mouse controls. Sort and edit records in the Data Table screen component. Customize screen flows with component-level style overrides. Send messages to large audiences and use Wait elements in asynchronous broadcast flows. Use decisions, exit rules, reentry conditions, and more in activation-triggered flows. Send Marketing Cloud Engagement emails in segment-triggered, event-triggered, activation-triggered, and broadcast flows. Trigger automation event-triggered flows when records related to an individual are changed.

notes.feature_name: Flow Approval Processes
notes.description: Complete approval step screen flows in Flow Builder while debugging flow approval processes without leaving Flow Builder. Start an autolaunched flow approval process from the new Request Approval component and let the submitter select the first approver.

notes.feature_name: Flow Orchestration Enhancements
notes.description: Create orchestrations and view orchestration dependencies with other automations in the Automation Lightning app. Complete orchestration work items in Flow Builder while debugging orchestrations without leaving Flow Builder.

notes.feature_name: Automation Lightning App Updates
notes.description: Find which Agentforce agents and prompt templates reference standard and custom invocable actions by using the Action Hub tab in the Automation Lightning app. Gain visibility into flow performance with the new Flow Logs tab in the Automation Lightning app.

notes.feature_name: MuleSoft for Flow: Integration
notes.description: MuleSoft for Flow: Integration is a no-code solution that connects your flows to external systems that use third-party connectors. Use these connectors as triggers or actions, creating seamless data and information exchange between systems.

notes.feature_name: MuleSoft for Flow: IDP
notes.description: Use MuleSoft for Flow: IDP to transform unstructured and semistructured data into structured, actionable output, enabling automation of document-based workflows. Organizations get lots of unstructured and semistructured documents that have important business data. But getting and processing this information by hand is time-consuming and can introduce mistakes. With MuleSoft for Flow: IDP you define what data to extract through custom configurations. You set confidence thresholds for automatic processing, and route low-confidence results for human review to verify.

notes.feature_name: Flow Builder Updates
notes.description: Make changes to record-triggered and scheduled-triggered flows using natural language. Make navigating the Flow Builder canvas easier with collapsible branching paths and more intuitive mouse scrolling controls. Access the Agentforce panel without admin setup.

notes.feature_name: Screen Flow Updates
notes.description: Sort and edit records in the Data Table component at runtime. Customize screen flows with component-level style overrides. Add colorful, a11y-compliant text to your screens with the new Message component. Streamline document-based screen flows with the File Preview component. Visualize and track progress with the Kanban Board component (beta).

notes.feature_name: Flow Marketing Cloud Updates
notes.description: Send Marketing Cloud Engagement emails in segment-triggered, event-triggered, activation-triggered, and broadcast flows. Trigger automation event-triggered flows when records related to an individual are changed. Get more control over schedule-triggered flows with more granular scheduling options. Use contact point selection rules to make sure your messages get to the right person. Send email messages using activation data.

notes.feature_name: Flow Data 360 Updates
notes.description: Send messages to large audiences and use Wait elements with asynchronous broadcast flows. Use decisions, exit rules, reentry conditions, and more in activation-triggered flows. Access segment-triggered, automation event-triggered, and on-demand flows with a Data 360 license.

notes.feature_name: Flow Testing and Debugging
notes.description: Save debug configurations when you save changes to a flow. Reuse tests from old flow versions.

notes.feature_name: Flow Runtime
notes.description: Versioned updates are available for flows that are configured to run on API version 66.0.

notes.feature_name: Flow Management
notes.description: Get insights into your flow’s health with version-level analytics. Compare different versions of a screen flow. View flow dependencies in the Automation Lightning app. Visualize flow performance directly in Flow Builder.

notes.feature_name: Flow Extensions
notes.description: Navigate to screen flows or autolaunched flows in Lightning Experience from custom Aura and Lightning web components.

notes.feature_name: Make changes to record-triggered and scheduled-triggered flows using natural language
notes.description: Make navigating the Flow Builder canvas easier with collapsible branching paths and more intuitive mouse scrolling controls. Access the Agentforce panel without admin setup.

notes.feature_name: Get More Accurate Draft Flows with AI
notes.description: Agentforce breaks down your business requirements into specific tasks and gives generative AI-specific instructions on how to complete those tasks, making your record-triggered or schedule-triggered flows more accurate. Enter your instructions and let AI do the work. You can also use and modify the sample instructions and then generate the draft flow.

notes.feature_name: Evolve Flows Iteratively with Agentforce
notes.description: Improve and modify existing record-triggered and schedule-triggered flows by using natural language without starting from scratch. Use conversational prompts in the Agentforce panel to add, modify, and delete elements in a flow. This feature doesn’t consume generative AI credits.

notes.feature_name: Simplify Your Flow Builder Layout by Collapsing Branching Elements
notes.description: Manage complex flows more efficiently by hiding unnecessary detail on the canvas. Now you can collapse and expand branching elements with Flow Builder, including Wait, Decision, Loop, Path Experiment, and Async Actions, helping you focus on the key parts of your flow. To ensure a consistent workflow, Flow Builder remembers your specific expand and collapse preferences. This layout is saved automatically and locally in your browser, making it easier to return to your work without changing the view for other users.

notes.feature_name: Set Up the Agentforce Panel Without Admin Configuration
notes.description: Users can now quickly transition to the Agentforce panel and access new features such as creating, summarizing, or evolving a flow. This feature doesn’t consume generative AI credits.

notes.feature_name: View Subflow Input and Output Variable Descriptions More Easily
notes.description: The infobubbles for subflow output variables now show the custom description set by the admin or developer. If no custom description is defined, improved default text guides you to assign a resource. Additionally, view descriptions for a subflow’s input resources in an infobubble even if the resource isn’t included. Previously, you had to enable the input resource to know whether you needed it.

notes.feature_name: View Action Input Descriptions More Easily
notes.description: Save time configuring flow actions. You can now hover over the infobubble next to an action input variable to view its description without including it. Upfront informational text helps you quickly understand why to use an input before deciding to assign it a value.

notes.feature_name: Navigate Flow Builder Faster with Enhanced Scrolling
notes.description: Navigating the Flow Builder canvas is now quicker and more intuitive. Previously, moving around the Flow Builder canvas required you to click and hold (grab and move) to pan across the elements.

notes.feature_name: Decision Logic Labels Were Updated for Clarity
notes.description: The labels for the Decision Logic section of the Decision element were changed to Define Manually (Default) and Define with AI (Advanced). The new labels clarify that defining conditions manually is now more intuitive.

notes.feature_name: Get More Accurate Draft Flows with AI
notes.description: Agentforce breaks down your business requirements into specific tasks and gives generative AI-specific instructions on how to complete those tasks, making your record-triggered or schedule-triggered flows more accurate. Enter your instructions and let AI do the work. You can also use and modify the sample instructions and then generate the draft flow.
notes.activation_required: Provision and enable Data 360 in your org. Then, turn on Einstein generative AI in Setup.
notes.edition: Essentials, Pro Suite, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer editions with Foundations or Agentforce 1 editions
notes.security_notes: This feature doesn’t consume generative AI credits.

notes.feature_name: Evolve Flows Iteratively with Agentforce
notes.description: Improve and modify existing record-triggered and schedule-triggered flows by using natural language without starting from scratch. Use conversational prompts in the Agentforce panel to add, modify, and delete elements in a flow. This feature doesn’t consume generative AI credits.
notes.activation_required: Provision and enable Data 360 in your org. Turn on Einstein generative AI in Setup. Then, open any existing record-triggered or schedule-triggered flow in Flow Builder. Opt in to migrate to Agentforce.
notes.edition: Essentials, Pro Suite, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer editions with Foundations or Agentforce 1 editions

notes.feature_name: Simplify Your Flow Builder Layout by Collapsing Branching Elements
notes.description: Manage complex flows more efficiently by hiding unnecessary detail on the canvas. Now you can collapse and expand branching elements with Flow Builder, including Wait, Decision, Loop, Path Experiment, and Async Actions, helping you focus on the key parts of your flow. To ensure a consistent workflow, Flow Builder remembers your specific expand and collapse preferences. This layout is saved automatically and locally in your browser, making it easier to return to your work without changing the view for other users.
notes.edition: Lightning Experience, Salesforce Classic in Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Set Up the Agentforce Panel Without Admin Configuration
notes.description: Users can now quickly transition to the Agentforce panel and access new features such as creating, summarizing, or evolving a flow. This feature doesn’t consume generative AI credits.
notes.edition: Essentials, Pro Suite, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions with Foundations or Agentforce 1 editions

notes.feature_name: View Subflow Input and Output Variable Descriptions More Easily
notes.description: The infobubbles for subflow output variables now show the custom description set by the admin or developer. If no custom description is defined, improved default text guides you to assign a resource. Additionally, view descriptions for a subflow’s input resources in an infobubble even if the resource isn’t included. Previously, you had to enable the input resource to know whether you needed it.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Custom Descriptions for Output Values
notes.description: When you select Manually assign variables (advanced), the infobubble next to each output value shows the custom description, replacing the previous generic message.

notes.feature_name: View Action Input Descriptions More Easily
notes.description: Save time configuring flow actions. You can now hover over the infobubble next to an action input.

notes.feature_name: Input Parameter Description in Flow Builder
notes.description: You can now view the description of an input parameter in Flow Builder without including it. This upfront informational text helps you quickly understand why to use an input before deciding to assign it a value.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer

notes.feature_name: Enhanced Scrolling in Flow Builder
notes.description: Navigating the Flow Builder canvas is now quicker and more intuitive. Previously, moving around the Flow Builder canvas required you to click and hold (grab and move) to pan across the elements. Now, you can use your mouse scroll wheel, trackpad, keyboard arrow keys, or the new scrollbars to pan the canvas and view different areas of the flow.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer

notes.feature_name: Decision Logic Labels Were Updated for Clarity
notes.description: The labels for the Decision Logic section of the Decision element were changed to Define Manually (Default) and Define with AI (Advanced). The new labels clarify that defining conditions manually is the first choice when working with structured data. When you can't define conditions because you're working with complex or unstructured data, use AI.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, and Unlimited editions with the Einstein for Sales, Einstein for Service, or Einstein Platform add-on

notes.feature_name: Organize Data Table Records with Column Sorting at Runtime
notes.description: Enable users to organize their view of records directly in the flow screen. By clicking column headers, users can sort records alphabetically or numerically at runtime. Previously, the Data Table component displayed records in a fixed order, requiring users to scan manually to find what they needed.

notes.feature_name: Edit Records Directly in the Data Table at Runtime
notes.description: Configure the Data Table component of a screen flow to support record editing at runtime. Previously read-only, the Data Table component now lets users modify values for specific field types. Confirmed changes are stored in the editedRows output parameter, making it easy to update records in Salesforce.

notes.feature_name: Tailor Screen Flows to Your Audience with Component-Level Styling Overrides
notes.description: Deliver a personalized screen flow experience to your customers. Customize a variety of style properties for your screen flows, like background color, border color, border weight, border radius, text color, buttons, and more. Any styling changes you set override your org or Experience Cloud site’s default theme.

notes.feature_name: Add Visually Distinct and Accessible Messages to Screen Flows
notes.description: With the new Message screen component, you can add an eye-catching a11y-compliant message to a screen to show information, a success, an error, or a warning.

notes.feature_name: Visualize and Track Record Progress with Kanban Boards in Screen Flows
notes.description: Use the new Kanban Board component to show records as cards in columns that represent workflow stages, without custom Lightning implementations. Your users gain instant visibility into record progress and record details without leaving the flow. The Kanban Board is read-only, so users can’t drag cards between stages at run time.

notes.feature_name: Preview Files Natively in Screen Flows
notes.description: Eliminate friction in document-based processes by enabling your users to review file content directly within a screen flow. The new File Preview screen component removes the requirement to download files externally, ensuring more streamlined document review and approval workflows.

notes.feature_name: Find and Select Flow Resources More Easily in Screen Flows
notes.description: Flow Builder extends the enhanced resource selection experience to screen elements. For example, improved grouping makes it easier for you to find the resources that you need, user-friendly labels are shown instead of API names, tooltips with descriptions are available so you know more about what resource you’re selecting, and the search experience allows for nested searches with breadcrumbs to keep track of where you are.

notes.feature_name: Open Screen Flows in Lightning Experience with a URL
notes.description: Launch screen flows in Lightning Experience and Lightning console apps with a new standardized URL format. Opening flows in Lightning has several benefits, such as faster performance, keeping your users in Lightning console apps, and providing a more consistent browser experience. You can also pass information into your flow through its URL. The new URL format also supports the Salesforce Cosmos theme, and flow local actions.

notes.feature_name: Organize Data Table Records with Column Sorting at Runtime
notes.description: Enable users to organize their view of records directly in the flow screen. By clicking column headers, users can sort records alphabetically or numerically at runtime. Previously, the Data Table component displayed records in a fixed order, requiring users to scan manually to find what they needed.
notes.activation_required: In a screen flow, configure the Data Table component columns to allow sorting.
notes.edition: Essentials, Pro Suite, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Data Sorting in Flow Runtime
notes.description: At flow runtime, users can sort data by clicking the supported column header. Sorting does not affect the underlying data structure.

notes.feature_name: Edit Records Directly in the Data Table at Runtime
notes.description: Configure the Data Table component of a screen flow to support record editing at runtime. Previously read-only, the Data Table component now lets users modify values for specific field types. Confirmed changes are stored in the editedRows output parameter, making it easy to update records in Salesforce.
notes.edition: Essentials, Pro Suite, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Update Supported Record and Apex Field Types
notes.description: At flow runtime, users can update the supported record and apex field types. When editing a field, users click Confirm to apply changes or Cancel to revert to the last confirmed value. If multiple rows are selected, users can update all selected items. To save changes, use the Edited Rows output collection. For example, add an Update Records element after the screen and set it to use the records stored in {!YourDataTableName.editedRows}.

notes.feature_name: Component-Level Styling Overrides for Screen Flows
notes.description: Deliver a personalized screen flow experience to your customers. Customize a variety of style properties for your screen flows, like background color, border color, border weight, border radius, text color, buttons, and more. Any styling changes you set override your org or Experience Cloud site’s default theme. This change applies to Lightning Experience and Salesforce Classic in Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, and Developer editions. This change also applies to Aura, LWR, and Visualforce sites accessed through Lightning Experience and Salesforce Classic in Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions. You must have at least one active community license in your org to use this feature. To customize the look for your screen, edit a screen. On the Screen Properties panel, select the Style tab. On the Style tab, you can set the styles for the header, container, and footer of your screen. You can customize the styling for these components: Checkbox, Checkbox Group, Currency, Date, Date/Time, Display Text, Number, Long Text Area, Multi-Select Picklist, Password, Picklist, Radio Button, Repeater, Section, and Text.

notes.feature_name: Add Visually Distinct and Accessible Messages to Screen Flows
notes.description: With the new Message screen component, you can add an eye-catching a11y-compliant message to a screen to show information, a success, an error, or a warning. The message type determines the color and icon used for the message. Screen readers are able to read the message type to their users. For the message, you can enter text or select a flow resource to use as the message.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Kanban Boards in Screen Flows
notes.description: Use the new Kanban Board component to show records as cards in columns that represent workflow stages, without custom Lightning implementations. Your users gain instant visibility into record progress and record details without leaving the flow. The Kanban Board is read-only, so users can’t drag cards between stages at run time.
notes.edition: Essentials, Pro Suite, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Enhanced Flow Board
notes.description: We added the Opportunity Type, Closed Date, Description, Has Overview Task, and Amount fields to the card content.

notes.feature_name: Preview Files Natively in Screen Flows
notes.description: Eliminate friction in document-based processes by enabling your users to review file content directly within a screen flow. The new File Preview screen component removes the requirement to download files externally, ensuring more streamlined document review and approval workflows.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Find and Select Flow Resources More Easily in Screen Flows
notes.description: Flow Builder extends the enhanced resource selection experience to screen elements. For example, improved grouping makes it easier for you to find the resources that you need, user-friendly labels are shown instead of API names, tooltips with descriptions are available so you know more about what resource you’re selecting, and the search experience allows for nested searches with breadcrumbs to keep track of where you are.

notes.feature_name: Open Screen Flows in Lightning Experience with a URL
notes.description: Launch screen flows in Lightning Experience and Lightning console apps with a new standardized URL format. Opening flows in Lightning has several benefits, such as faster performance, keeping your users in Lightning console apps, and providing a more consistent browser experience. You can also pass information into your flow through its URL. The new URL format also supports the Salesforce Cosmos theme, and flow local actions. To open a flow in Lightning Experience, append /lightning/flow/YourFlowNameHere to your URL. To run a specific flow version, append /lightning/flow/YourFlowNameHere/versionId to your URL. Flows that open in Lightning Experience have improved performance because most required Lightning components are already loaded into the browser session. In Lightning console apps, your tabs are preserved when a flow opens, and you can switch to other tabs while the flow is working. Using the new URL format also ensures that your browser behaves consistently, with forward, back, and your browser history working as expected. To pass data into a flow through its URL, append ?flow__variableIdHere=value to the end of your URL.

notes.feature_name: Send Marketing Cloud Engagement Emails from Flow Builder
notes.description: Send Marketing Cloud Engagement emails via segment-triggered, event-triggered, activation-triggered, or broadcast flows. The Send Marketing Cloud Engagement Email action efficiently targets Data 360 audience segments using your existing Marketing Cloud Engagement content and settings without requiring segment activation or data replication.

notes.feature_name: Ensure Recipients Don’t Get Duplicate Messages
notes.description: Use contact point selection rules to send messages to the right individual record and a single messaging contact point. This update improves message precision. The update also enables flows to retrieve contact points from source systems, so that a contact point can be selected even if identity resolution or the data graph has not been refreshed.

notes.feature_name: Send Email Messages Using Activation Data
notes.description: In activation-triggered flows, to include data from the activation in the Send Email Message action, use the $ActivationData variable in the email.

notes.feature_name: Run Segment-Triggered Flows at The Right Time with More Scheduling Options
notes.description: Run segment-triggered flows on customizable schedules for more control and precision. For example, run a flow every hour to ensure you're working with the latest data, or schedule flows to run only on weekdays to avoid weekend sends. New scheduling options include Hourly, Daily on Weekdays, Weekly on specific days, Monthly on specific days, and Yearly.

notes.feature_name: Get More Targeted Segments in Segment-Triggered Flows
notes.description: Create segment-triggered flows with segments built on Individual data model object (DMO) and engagement records, not just a Unified Individual DMO. For example, create a segment of all contacts converted yesterday. This update enables more precise targeting and provides access to engagement-specific data like order details or registration information.

notes.feature_name: Test Multiple Records in Segment-Triggered Flows in Debug
notes.description: Test up to 10 records simultaneously. Use the debug panel to instantly verify how different customers move through your flow. This update helps you quickly identify issues across diverse customer profiles before activation.

notes.feature_name: Trigger Automation Event-Triggered Flows When CRM Records Change
notes.description: Now you can trigger an automation event-triggered flow when a prospect, lead, or contact record changes, or when a record related to a prospect, lead, or contact record changes. For example, send a personalized email to a contact when a case is closed, or trigger a follow-up flow that notifies a lead owner when an opportunity moves to a new stage. This update helps you engage customers immediately when key business events occur, with prospect, lead, or contact data available for personalization in your messages.

notes.feature_name: Automatic In-App Notifications for Path Experiments
notes.description: Users who activate flows now receive automatic in-app notifications when path experiments are completed. Notifications cover winner selection, fallback handling, and inconclusive outcomes. This change keeps flow creators informed without requiring additional setup. If the activating user is deactivated, no notification is sent.

notes.feature_name: Path Comparison Analytics in Path Experiment Element
notes.description: Monitor path experiment results without leaving the Flow Builder canvas. The new Analytics tab in the Path Experiment element panel shows total participants, metrics, and confidence levels for path comparison. Monitor experiment results at a glance with this embedded summary, which is consistent with analytics available in other flow elements. To see in-depth analytics, click View Analytics.

notes.feature_name: Control Path Selection When Debugging Path Experiments
notes.description: Configure the Path Experiment element to randomize path assignment or manually select a winning path while debugging. Randomization is the default, but you can validate specific paths without relying on chance by using manual selection. With the manual selection configuration, you can test the exact path you want to validate.

notes.feature_name: View Path Experiment History
notes.description: Understand what happened during your path experiments with the new History tab. View all changes since activation, including timestamps, who made changes, and whether actions were automated or manual. Track events like experiment start, winner selection, delayed group releases, and fallback handling.

notes.feature_name: View Flow Run for Individual
notes.description: Troubleshoot specific customer issues by viewing the exact execution path that an individual took through a flow run. This capability shows you which branching paths were followed, what elements were completed, and where the individual potentially encountered errors or delays. This detailed view helps administrators investigate specific customer complaints, verify personalization logic, and identify bottlenecks for specific contacts in your marketing automation flows.

notes.feature_name: Personalize and Debug On-Demand Flows with Apex
notes.description: Personalize on-demand flows with Apex code and control processing priority when triggering flows via API. Select specific individuals and contact points to target messages. Debug flows with built-in debugging tools to test logic and identify issues before activation. Access help documentation from the start node to understand configuration options and best practices. These updates provide more flexibility for customizing flow behavior and faster troubleshooting during development.

notes.feature_name: Remove Individuals from Flows Externally via API
notes.description: Remove individuals from flows when external systems trigger exits via API. For example, exit customers from flows when they complete an order or when they reach a specified status. This update provides more flexibility to coordinate flow exits with external systems.

notes.feature_name: Automate Marketing Cloud Engagement Emails from Flow Builder
notes.description: Send Marketing Cloud Engagement emails via segment-triggered, event-triggered, activation-triggered, or broadcast flows. The Send Marketing Cloud Engagement Email action efficiently targets Data 360 audience segments using your existing Marketing Cloud Engagement content and settings without requiring segment activation or data replication.
notes.edition: Salesforce Enterprise and Unlimited editions with Marketing Cloud Engagement and Marketing Cloud Next

Flow automatically retrieves contact points using the method you select, ensuring messaging actions can execute successfully even for newly created individuals or when data is processing.

Debug flows with built-in debugging tools to test logic and identify issues before activation. Access help documentation from the start node to understand configuration options and best practices. These updates provide more flexibility for customizing flow behavior and faster troubleshooting during development.
notes.edition: Lightning Experience in Marketing Cloud Growth and Marketing Cloud Advanced editions, and Data 360 editions. This feature requires Data 360.

notes.feature_name: Remove Individuals from Flows Externally via API
notes.description: Remove individuals from flows when external systems trigger exits via API. For example, exit customers from flows when they complete an order or when they reach a specified status. This update provides more flexibility to coordinate flow exits with external systems. Configure exit rules that can be triggered via API. Use the new REST API endpoint to exit individuals from flows programmatically. When API calls are received, individuals are immediately removed. API-driven exit rules work across segment-triggered flows, automation event-triggered flows, and on-demand flows.
notes.edition: Lightning Experience in Foundations, Marketing Cloud Growth, and Marketing Cloud Advanced editions.

notes.feature_name: Flow Data 360 Updates
notes.description: Send messages to large audiences and use Wait elements with asynchronous broadcast flows. Use decisions, exit rules, reentry conditions, and more in activation-triggered flows.

notes.feature_name: Asynchronous Broadcast Flows
notes.description: You can now set broadcast flows to run asynchronously. By running the flow asynchronously, you can send notifications to larger audiences or to add Wait elements to the flow. That means you can resume the flow after a certain event triggers, like if a customer opens an email.
notes.activation_required: To run a broadcast flow asynchronously, in the Start element, select Async as the run type.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer, Marketing Cloud Growth, Marketing Cloud Advanced

notes.feature_name: Enhancements to Activation-Triggered Flows
notes.description: In activation-triggered flows, you can now use the Decision element, add exit and reentry conditions, pause an active flow, and in the Transform element, map activation data up to 5 levels deep.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer, Marketing Cloud Growth, Marketing Cloud Advanced

notes.feature_name: Data 360 License Enhancements
notes.description: Use segment-triggered, automation event-triggered, and on-demand flows in Data 360 with a Data 360 license. For example, create flows that trigger on segments or events or trigger flows via API from external systems. Create and use custom automation events in your flows. Data 360, Marketing Cloud Growth, and Marketing Cloud Advanced customers can now process up to 15 million actions per hour per org.
notes.edition: Data 360, Marketing Cloud Growth, Marketing Cloud Advanced

notes.feature_name: Label Change for Custom Real-Time Data Graph Event
notes.description: The label for the Custom Real-Time Data Graph Event automation event is now Real-Time Data Graph Record Change.

notes.feature_name: Exit Rules and Reentry Conditions in Flows
notes.description: To add exit rules and set reentry conditions, edit the flow’s Start element. You can reference the $ActivationData system variable to set exit rules based on the activation. To set reentry conditions, select a value for the Can Rejoin Flow field. Always is the default value and means an individual can reenter a flow before they exit. After completion means individuals can enter a flow only after they exit it. Never means that an individual can’t enter the flow again.

notes.feature_name: Use Flows with Data 360 Licenses and Increased Rate Limits
notes.description: Use segment-triggered, automation event-triggered, and on-demand flows in Data 360 with a Data 360 license. For example, create flows that trigger on segments or events or trigger flows via API from external systems. Create and use custom automation events in your flows. Data 360, Marketing Cloud Growth, and Marketing Cloud Advanced customers can now process up to 15 million actions per hour per org.
notes.edition: Data 360, Marketing Cloud Growth, Marketing Cloud Advanced

notes.feature_name: Label for Custom Real-Time Data Graph Event Was Changed
notes.description: The label for the Custom Real-Time Data Graph Event automation event is now Real-Time Data Graph Record Change. This change applies to Data Cloud in Enterprise, Performance, and Unlimited Editions. The label for the automation event is now more understandable.

notes.feature_name: Retain Debug Configurations Within Flow Editing Sessions
notes.description: Preserve debug configurations when you save changes to your flow. Debug inputs such as triggering record values, debug options, and input variable values now remain set when you save flow changes within your Flow Builder session. Refreshing your browser or closing Flow Builder clears all debug settings. To clear debug settings manually, click Reset Debug Settings.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer

notes.feature_name: Assign Flow Tests to Specific Flow Versions for More Control
notes.description: Reuse tests from previous flow versions if the scenario still applies to a new version. Align flow tests precisely with each flow version so updates don’t cause incorrect results from other flow versions. Previously, a flow test applied only to the latest flow version. You deleted previous tests that didn’t apply to the new flow version. For example, you deleted the flow test for flow version 1 after creating the flow test for flow version 2. Starting in Spring ’26, you associate the same test with multiple flow versions. Decide which test scenario is for which flow version. When you save a new flow version, the system automatically includes tests from the source flow version. From Flow Builder, open a record-triggered flow and create a flow test. Complete the test details. Then select the flow versions that you want to associate with the test. The flow test runs for the selected flow versions.

notes.feature_name: Flow and Process Run-Time Changes in API Version 66.0
notes.description: These updates affect only flows and processes that are configured to run on API version 66.0 or later. With versioned updates you can test and adopt run-time behavior changes for individual flows and processes at your convenience. To change the run-time API version of a flow, open it in Flow Builder and edit the flow version properties. To change the run-time API version of a process, open it in Process Builder and edit its properties.
notes.edition: Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Enforce No-Argument Constructor on Apex Classes
notes.description: With this versioned update, you can access certain built-in Apex classes that are available to be used as invocable action parameters. This versioned update enforces no-argument constructor visibility of all Apex classes, including the invocableVariable Apex class. Public no-argument constructors in managed packages are visible only when the access code is in the same package. An Apex action that refers to a non-visible no-argument constructor invocableVariable Apex class results in errors.

notes.feature_name: Record-Triggered Flows Issue with Non-Insertable Fields Was Fixed
notes.description: Record-triggered flows that run before records are saved now respect the internal writeable status of non-insertable fields. If existing flows try to update fields that aren’t editable, this error message appears: Invalid target field for field update.

notes.feature_name: Monitor Flow Performance with View Flow Version Run Analytics
notes.description: Get comprehensive insights into your flow version's overall health with new version-level analytics. Previously, understanding flow performance required piecing together data from individual element analytics or relying on incomplete aggregate metrics, which made it challenging to assess flow health holistically or spot systematic issues affecting multiple users. Now, you have a unified view showing completion rates, run status distributions, and detailed execution data across all individuals, so you can better monitor performance, identify version-wide trends, and share comprehensive insights with stakeholders.
notes.edition: Lightning Experience in Marketing Cloud Growth and Marketing Cloud Advanced
affected_components: Tableau Next Included App Business User

notes.feature_name: Compare Screen Flow Versions to Track Changes More Efficiently
notes.description: Use the Compare Versions feature to automatically track what’s changed between any two versions of a screen flow. View changes to screen flow elements, resources, fields, properties, components, and styles between flow versions.

notes.feature_name: View Flow Usage in the Automation Lightning App
notes.description: Understand flow dependencies with the new Usage subtab in the Automation Lightning app. The subtab shows bidirectional relationships, including which automations a flow version uses and which automation versions depend on that flow. This visibility helps you assess the impact of changes before modifying or deactivating flows.

notes.feature_name: Monitor Performance for Active and Previously Run Flows on the Canvas
notes.description: Visualize flow performance directly in Flow Builder. Previously, on-canvas insights were available only for flows triggered by Data 360. Now you can view aggregated element run data for active and previously run flows directly on the canvas to identify performance bottlenecks without relying on logs or external reporting tools. Embedded analytics aren’t available for screen flows or orchestrations.

notes.feature_name: View Flow Version Run Analytics
notes.description: View version analytics in Flow Builder by opening a flow with completed runs, clicking , and selecting View Flow Version Run Analytics from the dropdown menu. Review the summary panel for overview metrics, or click Open Details to access the comprehensive Tableau dashboard.

notes.feature_name: Compare Screen Flow Versions to Track Changes More Efficiently
notes.description: Use the Compare Versions feature to automatically track what’s changed between any two versions of a screen flow. View changes to screen flow elements, resources, fields, properties, components, and styles between flow versions.
notes.edition: Essentials, Pro Suite, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, Developer

notes.feature_name: Flow Version Comparison Sharing
notes.description: Share the flow version comparison results by using a direct link. Recipients can open the page with the flow versions preselected and the results displayed. If they change the flow versions and run the comparison again, a new link gets generated.

notes.feature_name: Flow Usage Visibility
notes.description: Understand flow dependencies with the new Usage subtab in the Automation Lightning app. The subtab shows bidirectional relationships, including which automations a flow version uses and which automation versions depend on that flow. This visibility helps you assess the impact of changes before modifying or deactivating flows.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Monitor Performance for Active and Previously Run Flows on the Canvas
notes.description: Visualize flow performance directly in Flow Builder. Previously, on-canvas insights were available only for flows triggered by Data 360. Now you can view aggregated element run data for active and previously run flows directly on the canvas to identify performance bottlenecks without relying on logs or external reporting tools. Embedded analytics aren’t available for screen flows or orchestrations.
notes.edition: Essentials, Pro Suite, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Navigate to Flows in Lightning Experience from Custom Lightning Components
notes.description: You can now navigate to a screen flow or autolaunched flow in Lightning Experience from a custom Aura or Lightning web component. Your Lightning component developer uses the Aura lightning:navigation component or the lightning/navigation Lightning web component to navigate to the new Standard Flow PageReference type or generate a URL from the PageReference.

notes.feature_name: Navigate to Flows in Lightning Experience from Custom Lightning Components
notes.description: You can now navigate to a screen flow or autolaunched flow in Lightning Experience from a custom Aura or Lightning web component. Your Lightning component developer uses the Aura lightning:navigation component or the lightning/navigation Lightning web component to navigate to the new Standard Flow PageReference type or generate a URL from the PageReference type.

notes.feature_name: Enforcing No-Argument Constructor on Apex Classes Used for Invocable Action Parameters
notes.description: When this update is enabled, you get access to certain built-in Apex classes that are available to be used as invocable action parameters. Additionally, this update enforces the visibility of the no-argument constructor on any class. This update was scheduled to be enforced in Summer ’26. Starting in Spring ’26, Salesforce no longer enforces this update, but we recommend that you enable it. This release update was previously named Enforce Permission Requirements Defined on Built-In Apex Classes Used as Inputs.
notes.timeline: Enforced in Summer ’26, recommended to enable starting Spring ’26

notes.feature_name: Sort Apex Batch Action Results by Request Order
notes.description: With this update enabled, Apex batch action results are shown in the order that the requests are received. Currently, error-prone requests are prioritized at the top of the result list, and successful requests are at the bottom.

notes.feature_name: Enforcing No-Argument Constructor on Apex Classes Used for Invocable Action Parameters
notes.description: When you enable this update, built-in Apex classes that were unavailable become available for Apex actions. Because of this change, the visibility of the no-argument constructor for the invocableVariable Apex class is also enforced. Public no-argument constructors in managed packages are no longer visible unless the access code is in the same package. An Apex action that refers to a non-visible no-argument constructor invocableVariable Apex class results in errors.
notes.availability: Scheduled to be enforced in Summer ’26, but Salesforce no longer enforces this update starting Spring ’26.
notes.activation_required: Follow the testing and activation steps in Release Updates.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions
notes.breaking_changes: Public no-argument constructors in managed packages are no longer visible unless the access code is in the same package.

notes.feature_name: Sort Apex Batch Action Results by Request Order
notes.description: With this update enabled, Apex batch action results are shown in the order that the requests are received. Currently, error-prone requests are prioritized at the top of the result list, and successful requests are at the bottom. After this update is applied, Apex batch action results are shown in the order that the requests are received.
notes.availability: Salesforce enforces this update in Summer ’26.
notes.activation_required: Follow the testing and activation steps in Release Updates.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Flow Approval Processes
notes.description: Complete approval step screen flows in Flow Builder while debugging flow approval processes without leaving Flow Builder. Start an autolaunched flow approval process from the new Request Approval component and let the submitter select the first approver.

notes.feature_name: Add Approval Submissions to Record Pages Without Custom Buttons
notes.description: Add a component for your users to submit records for approval without you creating a custom button. The Request Approval component works in both Lightning App Builder and Experience Builder. Configure built-in options for first approver selection and submission comments.

notes.feature_name: Complete Approval Work Items in Flow Builder While Debugging
notes.description: While debugging a flow approval process, open an approval work item directly on the canvas from the approval step’s card. After you complete the work item, the orchestration run resumes. Completing approval work items via email or by using the Review option from the Approval Work Items quick menu is unchanged.

notes.feature_name: View Flow Approval Process Automation Usage in the Approvals Lightning App
notes.description: Quickly identify dependencies for your flow approval processes with the new Usage subtab. Select the Manage All Flow Approval Processes tile to open the All Flow Approval Processes list view. Select a flow approval process or version, then click Usage. The subtab shows automations that the selected item uses or automations that use the selected item.

notes.feature_name: Debug Specific Segments of Flow Approval Processes
notes.description: Accelerate testing by debugging only a targeted stage or segment of your flow approval process. Define a start point to skip earlier elements, an end point to stop at a specific stage, or both to target a segment. When you set a start point, use the Configure Test Input tab to set input values for steps that rely on outputs from skipped stages or steps. To debug a single stage, set it as both the start point and the end point.

notes.feature_name: Control Which Flow Approval Process Steps to Run in Debug Mode with Test Output
notes.description: Use test output to debug flow approval process steps selectively in default mode. Skip steps that you don’t want to run to focus on specific parts of your flow approval process. This capability, previously called Manually Set Output, was available only in rollback mode. The Configure Test Output tab replaces the Configure Debug tab.

notes.feature_name: Add Approval Submissions to Record Pages Without Custom Buttons
notes.description: Add a component for your users to submit records for approval without you creating a custom button. The Request Approval component works in both Lightning App Builder and Experience Builder. Configure built-in options for first approver selection and submission comments.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, all Einstein 1, Developer editions

notes.feature_name: Autolaunched Flow Approval Process
notes.description: The component shows an Approval Request Comments field by default. To prevent the submitter from adding comments about a submission, select Hide submitter comments. To require the submitter to select a first approver, select Require submitter to select first approver.

notes.feature_name: Complete Approval Work Items in Flow Builder While Debugging
notes.description: While debugging a flow approval process, open an approval work item directly on the canvas from the approval step’s card. After you complete the work item, the orchestration run resumes. Completing approval work items via email or by using the Review option from the Approval Work Items quick menu is unchanged. This change applies to Lightning Experience in Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions. To debug a flow approval process, you must have the Manage Flow user permission.

Select the Manage All Flow Approval Processes tile to open the All Flow Approval Processes list view. Select a flow approval process or version, then click Usage. The subtab shows automations that the selected item uses or automations that use the selected item. This change applies to Lightning Experience in Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.

This capability, previously called Manually Set Output, was available only in rollback mode. The Configure Test Output tab replaces the Configure Debug tab.
notes.security_notes: To debug a flow approval process, you must have the Manage Flow user permission.

notes.feature_name: Other Changes to Flow Approval Processes
notes.description: Flow approval process designers can now: Provide input values and setup options one time per Flow Builder session instead of for every flow approval process debug run. Flow Builder preserves debug data such as triggering record inputs, debug options, and input variable values when you switch between Edit mode and Debug mode. Refreshing your browser or closing Flow Builder clears all debug settings. To clear debug settings manually, click Reset Debug Settings. Test input and test output that you set for steps aren't affected. Reduce email volume from approval work item notifications for individuals up the role hierarchy by using the new Send approval work item emails only to queue members setting. This approval setting limits notifications for queue-assigned approval steps to only queue members and their delegates. The setting has no effect if role hierarchy isn’t enabled. Use the Step panel’s Configure Test Output tab, previously known as Debug Configuration, to set test output values. The Manually Set Output Values option is now labeled Use Test Output. The new terminology reinforces that you’re specifying test values to use instead of running actual steps. All functionality remains the same. Place the Orchestration Work Guide, renamed from Flow Orchestration Work Guide, on the record page of an approval step’s related record in Experience Builder. Use the updated options in the Decision Logic section of the Decision element. See Decision Logic Labels Were Updated for Clarity.
notes.edition: Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, all Einstein 1, Developer

notes.feature_name: Create Orchestrations from the Automation Lightning App
notes.description: Start building orchestrations directly from the Automation Lightning app without going through Setup. Click New on the Orchestrations tab to open a filtered view of the New Automation window. Select the Autolaunched Automations or Triggered Automations category, and then select the specific orchestration type to create. Or search for the specific orchestration.

notes.feature_name: Complete Orchestration Work Items in Flow Builder While Debugging
notes.description: Complete orchestration work items while debugging an orchestration without leaving Flow Builder. Open the orchestration work item directly on the canvas from an interactive step’s card. After you complete the work item, the orchestration run resumes.

notes.feature_name: View Orchestration Automation Usage in the Automation Lightning App

The subtab shows automations that the selected item uses or automations that use the selected item.

notes.description: Orchestration designers can now provide input values and setup options one time per Flow Builder session instead of for every orchestration debug run. Flow Builder preserves debug data such as triggering record inputs, debug options, and input variable values when you switch between Edit mode and Debug mode. Refreshing your browser or closing Flow Builder clears all debug settings. To clear debug settings manually, click Reset Debug Settings.
